node.contents: In Java, is there any way to separate the steps that happen during object creation:

node.contents: In other words, are there high level constructs (maybe using refection?) that accurately map the bytecode instructions new (memory allocation) and invokespecial (object construction).

elements.contents: sun.misc.Unsafe /** Allocate an instance but do not run any constructor. Initializes the class if it has not yet been. */ public native Object allocateInstance(Class cls) throws InstantiationException; ---- Field f = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); f.setAccessible(true); Unsafe unsafe = (Unsafe) f.get(null); Integer integer = (Integer)unsafe.allocateInstance(Integer.class); System.out.println(integer); // prints "0"

node.contents: don't know how to do the 2nd part - invoke constructor on it.

node.contents: even with bytecode manipulation, you wont get access to the memory before the jlo constructor has exited normally.

astNode.text: even with bytecode manipulation, you wont get access to the memory before the jlo constructor has exited normally.

node.contents: No, there is no API (reflection or otherwise) for this in the JDK. You can however manipulate byte code itself, at runtime, using libraries that do that. For example, http://asm.ow2.org/

astNode.text: No, there is no API (reflection or otherwise) for this in the JDK. You can however manipulate byte code itself, at runtime, using libraries that do that. For example, http://asm.ow2.org/

node.contents: Umm, doesn't the base-class constructor execute *before* the derived-class constructor?

astNode.text: Umm, doesn't the base-class constructor execute *before* the derived-class constructor?

node.contents: @OliCharlesworth: The derived class constructor has to start with a call to the base-class constructor, but it's possible for the evaluation of that call's parameters to fail (e.g. if the derived constructor takes a parameter `foo` and calls the base constructor with value `1/foo`, calling the derived constructor with a `foo` value of zero would throw an exception before the base constructor executes).

astNode.text: @OliCharlesworth: The derived class constructor has to start with a call to the base-class constructor, but it's possible for the evaluation of that call's parameters to fail (e.g. if the derived constructor takes a parameter `foo` and calls the base constructor with value `1/foo`, calling the derived constructor with a `foo` value of zero would throw an exception before the base constructor executes).

node.contents: The JVM creates objects before they are given to the constructor; if a derived-class constructor throws an exception before chaining to the base-class constructor, I would expect that the derived class Finalize method will run on the object without any part of the base constructor ever having run.

astNode.text: The JVM creates objects before they are given to the constructor; if a derived-class constructor throws an exception before chaining to the base-class constructor, I would expect that the derived class Finalize method will run on the object without any part of the base constructor ever having run.
